awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Understanding complex wind-driven wildfire propagation patterns with a dynamical systems approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Intense and long wildfire seasons have unfortunately become a normal routine in certain parts of the US. Dangerous wildfires are often driven by intense winds. The chaotic nature of wind patterns makes prediction and fundamental understanding of wildfire growth a challenging task. Current wind-driven wildfire models are difficult to simulate and interpret. In this exploratory project, the key objective is to uncover hidden coherent patterns in wind data that could be used to better understand and predict wildfire growth driven by wind. The project will benefit society as it provides guidelines for wildfire management, which will save lives and reduce the financial burden on communities exposed to wildfires. 

In this study, dynamical systems theory will be employed to define coherent structures customized to the transport problems used to model wind-driven wildfire growth. A set of benchmark problems motivated by the field of dynamical systems and chaotic advection together with more complex realistic wind patterns will be leveraged to study the role of coherent structures in wildfire growth. Specifically, the hypothesis that generlized Lagrangian coherent structures could be defined to provide a template for wildfire growth under certain scenarios will be explored. Outreach activities in Utah will use visualization to demonstrate the importance of computer modeling in managing wildfires. This study will provide a new theory that not only simplifies our understanding of wildfire growth under complex wind patterns but also guides wildfire management and mitigation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the feasibility of leveraging classical dynamical systems theories to model wildfire transport, specifically focusing on the use of Lagrangian coherent structures (LCS) to predict and understand wildfire patterns under wind-driven scenarios. The role of wind velocity patterns on wildfire growth is complex due to the complexity and nonlinearity of the reacting flow equations involved. However, developing such models is crucial for improving our understanding of wildfire behavior and enhancing predictive capabilities.

 

The research conducted as part of this one-year EAGER project made several advances in developing computational tools for wildfire modeling. Significant achievements include the following highlights:

 

  • Revisiting the Asensio Wildfire Model:
  •   Performed a novel theoretical non-dimensionalization of the governing equations, introducing new non-dimensional parameters and scaling laws.
  •   Improved understanding of the fundamental physics involved in wildfire transport with theoretical analysis.
  • Development of a New Python Code:
  •   Developed a new Python code to solve wildfire equations using a compact finite difference scheme and the IMEX-RK method.
  •   The code supports CUDA and GPU processing for improved computational run time in advection-dominated regimes.
  • Benchmark Problems:
  •   Defined a steady flow topology problem based on flow around a saddle-type fixed point and extended to an unsteady double gyre flow to study the effect of Strouhal number on wildfire propagation.
  •   Quantitatively and qualitatively reported results on wildfire growth patterns and fire front propagation speed and studied the role of wind flow topology.
  • Scientific Machine Learning Integration:
  •   Applied our recently developed optimization algorithm (ADAM-SINDy) to infer wildfire equations and nonlinear parameters from data.
  • Firebrand Shower Module:
  •   Developed a scalable firebrand shower module using GPU kernels to simulate firebrand generation and transport.

 

The impact of this project extends into different disciplines such as wildfire modeling, computational fluid dynamics, and scientific machine learning. The project involved training a PhD student and a Masters student at the intersection of computational fluid dynamics, high-performance computing, and reactive flow modeling. The PhD student attended the Princeton-Combustion Institute Summer School on Combustion and the Environment, which significantly contributed to their professional development. Other activities included presenting research at the APS Division of Fluid Dynamics meeting and planning to release the developed software on PI's lab's Github page.
